I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  After the high-level forum on the draft State Poverty Reduction Program (SPRP) in April 
2002, the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan (the Government) reiterated its request for 
a follow-up technical assistance (TA) to build the capacity of national and local governments to 
reduce poverty. The TA1 was included in the Kazakhstan Country Strategy and Program Update 
for 2002. An Asian Development Bank (ADB) fact-finding mission was conducted from 28 
August to 13 September 2002, and reached an agreement with the Government on the TA 
objective, scope, cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation arrangements. The TA 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since 1999, Kazakhstan has achieved positive and rising gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth rates, from 2.7% in 1999 to 9.8% in 2000 and 13.2% by 2001, resulting in a decline in 
poverty incidence,2 albeit at less than the pace of the GDP growth rate. By 2001, government 
statistics showed that the poor made up more than one fourth of the total population and that 
the total unemployed were more than 780,000, or 10.4% of the economically active population. 
While poverty incidence may have declined nationally, the headcount poverty index varied 
widely across oblasts.3 The headcount poverty index ranged from a low of less than 10% in 
Astana City, to 52% in Mangistau. Nonincome poverty indicators showed disturbing trends. 
Based on government statistics, infant and maternal mortality remained high, and tuberculosis 
(TB) incidence was rising. Pavlodar, an industrial oblast, recorded one of the country’s highest 
infant mortality rates (25 deaths per 1,000 born) and had higher-than-average incidences of 
cancer (246.1 per 100,000 people) and TB (196.2 per 100,000 people). Almaty, an agricultural 
oblast, had higher rural poverty than the national average and recorded high rates of infectious 
and parasitic disease.  
 
3.  The President of Kazakhstan is scheduled to sign the SPRP for 2003–2005 as a state 
program before the end of the year. The Government is also drafting the 3-year action plan for 
the SPRP, and the oblasts are finalizing their poverty reduction programs. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
1 The TA first appeared in the ADB Business Opportunities (Internet Edition) on 30 August 2002. 
2 The Government’s National Statistics Agency (NSA) uses “subsistence minimum” to measure poverty incidence 
(the percentage of the total population whose consumption expenditures fall below the subsistence minimum). The 
subsistence minimum comprises 70% food items and 30% goods and services, excluding the cost of public utilities. 
It is derived from the data set of the living standards measurement survey developed for the country with World 
Bank assistance in 1996, and was refined and updated by NSA in 2001. Subsistence minimum is differentiated 
from the “poverty line,” which, in Kazakhstan, is determined by law as a fixed percentage of the subsistence 
minimum. The Ministry of Labor and Social Protection establishes the poverty line and uses it to estimate 
budgetary allocations for social assistance, or cash transfers to poor households. Using the international standard 
of $2.15 a day per capita income (at purchasing power parity standard) as the poverty threshold, the World Bank 
estimated poverty incidence at 5.7% in 1996. Data on poverty incidence using the international poverty line 
yardstick is not updated, but assuming the same downward trend of poverty incidence based on subsistence 
minimum, the headcount poverty level using the international poverty threshold would be roughly 5 %.  
3  An oblast is an administrative unit equivalent to a region. Kazakhstan has 14 oblasts.

2 
4.  To track the effectiveness of the SPRP in reducing poverty, 18 outcome indicators have 
been identified.4 With the exception of four indicators that gauge direct and indirect interventions 
for the poor, the rest focus on direct interventions extended to the poor. A third of these 14 
indicators relate to employment for the poor while the rest served to measure delivery of social 
services that directly impact on the poor.  
 
5.  While the SPRP identifies the monitoring indicators, it does not specify the monitoring 
and evaluation (M&E) system that will clearly delineate the roles, functions, and relations of the 
concerned agencies and local governments in tracking the indicators. At the national level, the 
Ministry of Economy and Budget Planning (MEBP), which serves as the secretariat to the 
Interministerial Committee on Poverty Reduction, oversees and coordinates the M&E of the 
SPRP. However, because of inadequate technical capacity, MEBP has not been able to set up 
a  M&E  system  that  will  effectively  relate  the  activities  of  concerned  agencies  and  local 
governments.  
 
6.  While the National Statistics Agency (NSA) compiles most of the impact (or outcome) 
indicators of the poverty reduction programs, the data source for most of the indicators and the 
main implementers of the direct poverty-related interventions are the Ministry of Labor and 
Social Protection (MLSP) and the akimats.5 MLSP compiles data on labor and employment, the 
subsistence minimum and poverty line (footnote 2), and the extremely poor and their key 
features; and implements labor and social assistance programs down to the local levels. MLSP 
has developed a database management system but lacks the technical skills and equipment to 
link its local offices and MEBP. MLSP also needs the skills to evaluate and analyze the findings 
from its monitoring activities and assess the impact of its direct poverty reduction programs.  
 
7.  Because of decentralization, the akimats have the budget and authority to plan, manage, 
implement, and control poverty-related social and economic projects in the akimats’ territorial 
jurisdiction. The akimats are also finalizing their SPRPs, which means that delivery of social 
services to the poor lies essentially in the akimats’ hands. M&E of the SPRPs will be important 
to identify bottlenecks or problems during implementation to solve them as soon as possible, 
and to provide feedback to the central Government on measures to ensure that the countrywide 
SPRP objectives are achieved.  
 
8.  Aside from M&E system, a feedback mechanism must be developed to keep national 
policymakers abreast of the status and progress of the poverty reduction strategy, and to 
provide beneficiaries with a mechanism to register their level of satisfaction on service provision 
and delivery. Government and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) must be involved in M&E 
to  ensure  transparency  in  the  implementation  of  government  poverty  programs  and  exact 
accountability from the providers of these measures.6  
 
                                                 
4  The  18  indicators  are  GDP  per  capita,  percentage  of  people  below  minimum  subsistence  level,  level  of 
unemployment, percentage of economically active population employed in small business, number of microcredits 
given, number of retrained registered unemployed, number of employed at public works, percentage of people 
without access to potable water, percentage of rural families without telephones, number of people receiving 
targeted social assistance, percentage of people receiving assistance from among the population living below 
subsistence minimum, coverage of 5–6  year olds by preschooling training, TB mortality, TB incidence of TB, infant 
mortality, maternal mortality, and average lifespan of population. 
5  Akimats are local governments. 
6  International  experience  shows  that  undertaking  M&E  and  providing  feedback  mechanisms  for  the  target 
beneficiaries to register their satisfaction rating ensures immediate response from the Government to problems 
arising from the implementation of these activities and reduces income and nonincome poverty.

3 
9.  Finally, the indicators specified in the SPRP generally do not reflect the diverse features 
of poverty at the oblast level and are not able to gauge the akimats’ performance in combating 
poverty.7 The indicators also focus on the final outcomes of the goods and services produced by 
government measures. More effective indicators are those that complement these outcome 
indicators with intermediate indicators or inputs and outputs, and the implementation process; 
and explain or contribute to the results of the outcomes.8 Monitoring indicators disaggregated by 
geographic or administrative unit and program will also provide policymakers better information 
on the causes and sources of success of, or gaps in, the intervention measures, and enable 
policymakers to timely adjust specific program components.  
 
10.  The TA will address these concerns by helping the Government pilot-test an oblast-level 
M&E system and a feedback and advocacy mechanism linked to and coordinated by MEBP. 
Linkage of oblast-based M&E offices with one central service-providing agency, MLSP, and 
coordinated with MEBP, will also be test-cased. The lessons from these experiences will help 
the central Government design mechanisms in the oblasts and nationwide to improve poverty 
reduction, adjust the SPRP outcome monitoring indicators so that they focus on the key poverty 
issues, and ensure that poverty is eradicated. A summary initial poverty and social analysis of 
the TA is in Appendix 2.  
11.  The TA is a follow-through activity of TA 3550-KAZ: Preparation of a Comprehensive 
Medium-Term Poverty Reduction Strategy, which helped the Government formulate the SPRP 
in a participatory manner. The SPRP poverty analysis highlights the need to address regional 
disparities and involve the akimats in the program. The TA findings will lay the groundwork to 
develop the poverty reduction partnership agreement between the Government and ADB. The 
TA will also benefit from a recently approved small-scale TA9 (SSTA). It will undertake a public 
expenditure review of the education and health sectors at the concerned ministry and two 
oblasts from January to April 2003. The SSTA lessons will serve as inputs to the M&E system to 
be established under the TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The TA’s purpose is to develop an efficient and transparent SPRP M&E and feedback 
system at the national and oblast levels by pilot-testing alternative institutional arrangements 
and capacity building for poverty monitoring, evaluation, and feedback on the Government’s 
performance in implementing the SPRP. The outputs will include (i) a poverty M&E system, (ii) a 
feedback and advocacy mechanism to disseminate the findings from the M&E activities, and (iii) 
analytical  skills  in  monitoring  and  evaluating  government  attainment  of  poverty  reduction 
targets. 
  
                                                 
7 For example, one monitoring indicator is GDP. Oil-rich Manistee and Atyrau, with the highest oblast GDP, registered 
very high poverty incidence at 52% and 41%, respectively. 
8 One of the SPRP indicators is TB incidence, which continued to rise from 1996 to 2001 despite increases in the 
budget for TB programs. Key inputs to be monitored are the budget allocated for the TB program and the use and 
allocation of the funds for preventive versus curative measures disaggregated by regions and types of target 
beneficiaries. 
9 ADB. 2002. Small-Scale Technical Assistance for the Social Sector Expenditure Review in Kazakhstan. Manila.

4 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The M&E and feedback system will be set-up and test-cased in Pavlodar and Almaty, 
which  were  selected  in  consultation  with  government  officials  in  central  offices  using  the 
following: (i) economic sector focus—Pavlodar is industrial while Almaty is rural; (ii) income-
generating capacity—Pavlodar is a “donor” oblast in the sense that part of its local revenues is 
allocated  to  low-income  oblasts,  while  Almaty  is  a  “recipient”  or  a  low-income  oblast;  (iii) 
willingness and capacity of the akimats to implement the M&E system; and (iv) availability of an 
oblast-level SPRP. 
 
14.  In these two oblasts, the monitoring indicators of the national and oblast SPRPs will be 
reviewed, and key input, output, and outcome poverty indicators identified. The appropriate 
monitoring techniques as well as the evaluation and feedback approaches will be test-cased 
through a combination of (i) technical advice on the intermediate indicators for the direct poverty 
interventions of the akimats and MLSP, database development and management, monitoring 
tracking  systems,  and  process  and  impact  evaluation  techniques;  (ii)  intensive  training  of 
technical staff of MEBP and MLSP at the oblast and central offices, and of other local public 
staff members who will be involved in the M&E and feedback system; and (iii) provision of 
equipment  and  software  to  oblast  and  central  offices  of  MEBP  and  MLSP  for  database 
management and M&E. To encourage NGO involvement in M&E, small-scale surveys and 
studies assessing the satisfaction level of targeted beneficiaries of poverty interventions will be 
encouraged on a competitive basis. The TA will also help MEBP define its coordination role and 
develop the overall supervisory structure of the poverty M&E and feedback system at the central 
level.  
 
15.  The TA outputs will be disseminated through the feedback mechanism, comprising a 
web site, bulletins, and media conferences.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total TA cost is estimated at $966,000 equivalent, consisting of $422,000 in foreign 
exchange costs and $544,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will finance $676,000 
equivalent to cover the entire foreign exchange cost and $254,000 equivalent of the local 
currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
Government will fund the remaining local currency cost of $290,000 equivalent. Government 
financing will cover remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff, office accommodation and 
equipment, workshop expenses, translation and interpretation, and transport. Details of the cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MEBP will be the TA Executing Agency while MLSP and the Department of Economy 
and Budget Planning (DEBP) in Pavlodar and Almaty will serve as the implementing agencies 
(IAs),  MEBP  will  set  up  the  poverty  M&E  and  feedback  systems  in  the  two  oblasts,  and 
coordinate  with  MLSP  to  develop  the  feedback  mechanism  to  the  akimats  and  to  the 
Interministerial  Committee  on  Poverty  Reduction,  the  findings  from  the  evaluation  and 
assessment studies. At the end of the TA, MEBP will ensure that the TA lessons can serve as 
the basis to institute national and local poverty M&E and feedback system.  
 
18.  The oblast DEBP, which reports directly to the akimat level and the central MEBP, will 
establish a poverty monitoring and evaluation group (PMEG) with the economic and social

5 
working groups, involving the concerned departments at the oblast level. The working groups 
will set up the M&E and feedback system that will track performance at the oblast level and the 
social and economic programs that impact on poverty. The PMEG will review and identify the 
key input, output, and outcome poverty indicators relevant to the oblasts; set up mechanisms to 
assess in a participatory manner the level of satisfaction of targeted beneficiaries on the poverty 
reduction  programs  in  the  oblasts;  and  develop  a  mechanism  to  provide  feedback  to  the 
akimats, central MEBP, and Interministerial Committee on Poverty Reduction on the monitoring 
indicators and the findings from the evaluation and assessment studies.  
 
19.  The local MLSP, which reports directly to the central MLSP, will be a member of the 
PMEG and provide it with the income and nonincome information about the poor and extremely 
poor, as well as evaluation assessments of MLSP employment and social assistance programs. 
This  information  will  be  reported  to  the  akimats,  central  MEBP  and  MLSP,  and  the 
Interministerial Committee on Poverty Reduction to improve their social service delivery.  
 
20.  The TA will support training, seminars, and workshops of PMEG, MLSP, and MEBP staff 
on  the  quantitative  and  qualitative  approaches  to  monitoring  and  evaluating  the  poverty 
reduction activities; advocacy and feedback approaches, and pro-poor budgeting; as well as the 
identification of the intermediate, output, and outcome indicators. The training, seminars, and 
workshops will be done by the consultants and resource persons in close coordination with the 
MEBP and ADB. The TA will collaborate with the World Bank Institute and Asian Development 
Bank Institute on the training activities. Both institutes are planning poverty-related training. The 
TA  will  also  finance  the  cost  of  small-scale  studies  and  beneficiary  rating  surveys  to  be 
conducted by local NGOs selected on a competitive basis by the ADB. DEBP and MLSP will 
fund surveys that will be used in evaluating the level of efficiency and effectiveness in delivering 
the poverty reduction activities.   
 
21.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 1 year, from January 2003 to January 2004. 
It  will  finance  42  person-months  of  consulting  services,  comprising  7  person-months  for 
international and 35 person-months for domestic consultants. The consultants will help the 
MEBP, MLSP and DEBP set up the poverty M&E and feedback system in the two pilot oblasts, 
MLSP, and MEBP; and provide technical advice and training in M&E approaches. The terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. The consultants will be selected and engaged 
through a consulting firm following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The quality- and 
cost-based selection method and simplified technical proposal format will be used. Equipment 
will be procured by the consultants with procedures acceptable to ADB.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $676,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan for the Capacity Building of National and Local 
Governments to Implement the Poverty Reduction Program, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

SUMMARY INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Kazakhstan: 
 
While income poverty has declined in recent years, poverty incidence varies across oblasts. Nonincome 
poverty indicators, as shown by key health and education indicators, have displayed disturbing trends 
among the oblasts.  
  
Recognizing these emerging issues, the Government has drafted the State Poverty Reduction Program 
(SPRP), which will be signed before the end of the year. Each oblast has also been tasked to draft a 
poverty reduction program, tailored to the SPRP.  
  
The SPRP has some limitations that may not ensure effective poverty reduction. First, although the SPRP 
has 18 outcome indicators, it does not specify a monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system involving local 
governments and service providers despite the fact that 14 of the 18 indicators relate to delivery of social 
services and other direct poverty reduction interventions. The main providers of these pro-poor social 
services and measures are the local governments and the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection 
(MLSP). While the Ministry of Economy and Budget Planning (MEBP) has been tasked to coordinate the 
M&E of the measures, it does not have the skills to do so. Second, even if these service delivery units 
were involved, their staff do not have the technical M&E skills. Third, the indicators focus on final 
outcomes that are general and do not specify the intermediate indicators that monitor implementation. 
Fourth, the SPRP does not have a feedback mechanism to convey evaluation assessments to the main 
policymakers to allow them to act in a timely manner. Targeted beneficiaries must register their level of 
satisfaction with service delivery. 
  
The technical assistance (TA) will develop, on a pilot basis, an M&E and feedback system for SPRP 
implementation, involving local governments in two oblasts, MLSP, and MEBP, and improve their 
technical staff’s capacity. With a more efficient and effective M&E and feedback system, the key central 
government service delivery units will be encouraged to improve their delivery of services to the poor, 
which, in turn, will eventually reduce nonincome and income poverty. The TA is envisaged to lead to 
institutionalization of an efficient and transparent M&E and feedback system for the SPRP. In the medium 
term, this will improve delivery of poverty reduction measures and reduce poverty.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis      Proposed Classification: Poverty Intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
As poverty monitoring indicators and technical skills in poverty M&E improve, the poverty analysis will 
focus on the process of evaluating poverty reduction measures, and its impact on the multidimensional 
features of poverty. The analysis will be disaggregated at the oblast, sector, and poverty group levels, 
and will employ quantitative and qualitative approaches. The feedback system will let the targeted 
beneficiaries register their level of satisfaction with the Government’s direct poverty interventions and 
allow stakeholders to be involved in M&E of poverty reduction programs. With appropriate advocacy of 
these findings, central policymakers will be able to adjust their programs to reduce poverty. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Stakeholder analysis:  
 
Government and selected nongovernment organizations (NGOs) were consulted during the Fact-Finding 
Mission to find out who should be involved in M&E of poverty reduction measures, how these people 
perceive their role in M&E of poverty reduction programs, what their technical and resource limitations 
are, what indicators are needed to assess the performance of service delivery units, the viability of

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will support the Government in developing a poverty 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E) and feedback system by pilot-testing it in two oblasts and 
involving the Ministry of Economy and Budget Planning (MEBP) and Ministry of Labor and 
Social Protection (MLSP). The consultants will be selected and engaged through a consulting 
firm following the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The 
quality-and-cost-based selection method and simplified technical proposal format will be used.   
 
B.  Consultants’ Terms of Reference 
 
2.  The TA will need a total of 42 person-months of consulting services: 7 for international 
consultants and 35 for domestic consultants. The consultants will fill the positions and meet the 
technical skills described in the following paragraphs. 
 
1.  International Lead Consultant (5 person-months) 
 
3.  ADB will recruit the lead consultant, who will have extensive experience in poverty 
monitoring and evaluation (M&E) and in poverty strategy formulation in Central Asia and/or 
Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) countries, strong knowledge of the socioeconomic-
political conditions in Kazakhstan, good working relations with Government, and ability to speak 
fluent Russian and English. The consultant will serve as the team leader and coordinate the 
TA’s  overall  activities.  Together  with  the  domestic  and  international  consultants,  the  lead 
consultant will work closely with the MEBP, akimats, and MLSP on developing an effective M&E 
and feedback system. The lead consultant will have the following responsibilities:  
  
(i)  Supervise the review of the monitoring indicators at the oblast level and help 
develop the M&E and feedback framework and action plan of the oblast’s poverty 
reduction strategy for 2003–2005. 
(ii)  Help review the data for the poverty monitoring indicators, oversee the database 
management at the oblast level, and identify the poverty predictors for evaluation 
of the poverty outcomes and impact.  
(iii)  Review the experience of other countries in setting up a comprehensive M&E 
and feedback system, and generate lessons from them.  
(iv)  Identify the training needs for evaluation and analysis of the monitoring indicators 
and oversee the design and implementation of the training at the ministerial and 
oblast levels. 
(v)  Ensure that individuals and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) undertaking 
policy  research  studies  and  qualitative  assessments  will  be  identified  and 
selected on a competitive basis; and ensure that the quality of their output—
methodology,  theoretical  framework,  and  analysis—is  well  developed  and 
conceptually sound. 
(vi)  Develop  an  M&E  and  feedback  system  that  ensures  participation  and 
involvement of major stakeholders. 
(vii)  Ensure  a  mechanism  to  provide  regular  reports  to  MEBP  and  ADB  on  the 
progress of poverty M&E at the oblast level.

(viii)  Consolidate the experiences learned from the pilot-testing of the TA, provide a 
strategy paper on policy and institutional reforms to ensure effective and efficient 
implementation of the M&E and feedback system to be presented with the MEBP 
to the Interministerial Commission on Poverty Reduction.  
 
2.  International Pro-Poor Budgeting Specialist (1 person month) 
 
4.  The international financial specialist will have work experience in Central Asia and/or 
CIS countries (experience in Kazakhstan is an advantage) and have professional expertise in 
pro-poor  budgeting  and  development  economics.  The  consultant  will  perform  the  following 
tasks: 
 
(i)  Develop a pro-poor budget expenditure tracking system tailored to oblast and 
ministry levels to trace fund use and allocation for specific poverty projects from 
the national budget down to their expected beneficiaries. 
(ii)  Help design reporting procedures of the budget by expenditure for each poverty 
project to ensure transparency and accountability. 
(iii)  Develop efficiency and efficacy tests for financial use and allocation that relate 
these to the poverty monitoring outcomes.  
(iv)  Design the appropriate training program for the technical staff at the oblast and 
ministry levels on the process and impact evaluation approaches. 
(v)  Report on accomplishments and further actions to be taken at the end of the 
consulting work. 
 
3.  International Programmer and Econometrician (1 person-month) 
 
5.  The programmer should preferably have a background in economics and development, 
with  expertise  in  poverty  database  management,  and  work  experience  in  Central  Asia 
(preferably Kazakhstan) and/or CIS countries. The specialist will be required to do the following: 
 
(i)  Identify the poverty data and predictors as well as the quantitative approaches to 
analyze the poverty monitoring indicators and suitable computer applications and 
software for analysis.  
(ii)  Develop a program that will effectively and efficiently network the poverty M&E 
data at the oblast level to the MEBP and MLSP. 
(iii)  Ensure  the  installation  of  the  system,  computer  support  system,  and  its 
maintenance by the oblast departments and ministries.  
(iv)  Help MLSP and its Department of Social Protection and Employment at the 
oblast levels develop a program that will enable the agency to improve and 
enhance the poverty data classified by low-income categories (extremely poor, 
poor, and vulnerable poor), target groups, and vulnerable groups. 
(v)  Train staff in evaluation and feedback techniques at the oblast and ministry 
levels. 
(vi)  Report on accomplishments and further actions to be taken at the end of the 
consulting work.

4.  Domestic Consultant with Expertise in Poverty Reduction and Advocacy 
(12 person-months) 
 
6.  The  specialist  will  be  an  economist  with  extensive  knowledge  of  poverty  reduction 
strategies and advocacy approaches, work experience in oblast development in Kazakhstan, 
and good working relations with government and civil society. The expert will have the following 
functions: 
 
(i)  Oversee and coordinate the poverty M&E activities in the two oblasts. 
(ii)  Develop a feedback and advocacy mechanism to convey the analytical findings 
from the assessment of monitoring indicators to the major policymakers at the 
national and oblast (oblast and village akimats and local legislators) levels. 
(iii)  Organize the training and workshops for those involved in M&E at the oblast and 
ministry levels.  
(iv)  Ensure the broad participation of major stakeholders in feedback and advocacy.  
(v)  Together  with  the  MLSP  and  MEBP,  design  the  procedure  for  competitive 
selection of individuals and nongovernment organizations (NGOs) undertaking 
the surveys and studies, and ensure mechanisms for quality control (through 
peer  reviews  and  other  similar  processes)  and  timely  dissemination  of  their 
output. 
(vi)  Write up the lessons learned and recommendations arising from the TA and 
ascertain that the Government will institutionalize the M&E and feedback system.  
(vii)  Together with the team leader, provide regularly progress reports to the EA and 
ADB. 
(viii)  Perform the project’s administrative responsibilities. 
 
5.  Domestic Social Sector Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
7.  The specialist will have extensive knowledge of poverty reduction strategies for social 
sector development, work experience on oblast development in Kazakhstan, and good working 
relations  with  government  and  civil  society.  The  specialist  will  work  directly  with  the  local 
government technical staff and undertake the following roles: 
 
(i)  Help review and evaluate the monitoring indicators for health, education, social 
protection, and employment generation at the oblast level. 
(ii)  Help identify the intermediate (input and output during poverty reduction) and 
final (outcomes and impact) monitoring indicators.  
(iii)  Analyze the indicators in relation to the national Poverty Reduction Program and 
international poverty-related indicators. 
(iv)  Ensure beneficiary assessments on the access, use, and level of satisfaction in 
the provision and delivery of social services through involvement of NGOs. 
(v)  Help train staff in M&E and provide feedback on the social programs that impact 
on poverty at the oblast and national levels.  
(vi)  Identify key lessons learned and generated from the pilot-testing experience, and 
recommend policy and institutional reforms to improve social service delivery and 
reduce poverty. 
(vii)  Report on accomplishments and further actions to be taken at the end of the 
consulting work.

6.  Domestic Pro-Poor Budgeting Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
8.  The specialist will be an economist and/or development economist, have experience in 
pro-poor budgeting, have work experience in public budget management at the oblast level, and 
demonstrate good working relations with government and civil society. The specialist will work 
directly with the local government technical staff and perform the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Oversee the pro-poor budgeting tracking system and the efficiency and efficacy 
tests of the poverty reduction projects at the oblast and ministry levels.  
(ii)  Review the lessons learned from the small-scale TA on social expenditure review 
in Kazakhstan, incorporate the good experiences, and address the concerns. 
(iii)  Address problems encountered in the system and modify where appropriate. 
(iv)  Help  prepare  reports  and  assessments  for  broad  dissemination  and,  where 
necessary, for advocacy to improve the use and allocation of public resources 
defrayed for local and national poverty reduction projects.  
(v)  Help identify the intermediate (input and output during poverty reduction) and 
final (outcome and impact) monitoring indicators. 
(vi)  Ensure “report card” assessments that enable intended beneficiaries to evaluate 
government pro-poor growth approaches by involving NGOs and the private 
business sector.  
(vii)  Prepare a strategy paper to institutionalize the financial expenditure tracking 
system at the oblast and national levels. 
(viii)  Report on accomplishments and further actions to be taken at the end of the 
consulting work. 
  
7.  Domestic Programmer and Statistician (6 person-months) 
 
9.  The  domestic  programmer  cum  statistician  should  have  experience  in  database 
management of poverty data, knowledge of regional poverty issues, and good working relations 
with government and civil society. Together with the international programmer, the consultant 
will perform the following roles: 
 
(i)  Identify the poverty-related data, collect and consolidate the poverty data at the 
oblast and village levels, and address poverty data gaps. 
(ii)  Develop a system to harmonize and standardize poverty-related data to be used 
for the poverty M&E and feedback system. 
(iii)  Ensure database networking and information dissemination. 
(iv)  Help train staff in quantitative and qualitative approaches to analyze the poverty 
monitoring indicators. 
(v)  Ensure the maintenance of the poverty database at the oblast and national level.  
(vi)  Prepare a strategy paper that will ensure the sustainability of the poverty M&E 
and feedback system after the TA. 
(vii)  Report on accomplishments and further actions to be taken at the end of the 
consulting work.
